9.text: It's incredibly important to consider condition when looking at paintings from this period

14.text: because it can tell us quite a lot.

17.text: Every painting has a really personal history.

19.text: Two pictures painted at the same time in the same studio by the same artist,

24.text: going to live in different country houses, and later perhaps museums or institutions,

30.text: will have had very different lives and the result of their lives would tell on the surface of the painting.

37.text: From a museum perspective, we're not usually trying to restore a painting back to the way

42.text: it would have looked when it was first painted and it's not usually desirable to do so

46.text: because we are talking about pictures here that are often over four hundred years old

50.text: and the sense of the authenticity of that object comes from a sense of its character and its age.

55.text: When we're undertaking conservation work, rather than restoration work,

60.text: we're looking to restore what is there, what is left after the passage of time,

65.text:
rather than to remake what the image 
would have looked like originally.

69.text: The careful conservation treatment of these three paintings has allowed us to learn a lot more

75.text: about the way they were painted and what they might well have meant to their first audiences.

82.text: With this picture, the so-called 'Phoenix' portrait of Elizabeth I,

86.text: the very painstaking conservation treatment has brought the picture back to life,

92.text:
revealing original details 
that have been concealed for centuries.

97.text: This very complicated costume has been captured in all its amazing intricacy:

104.text: from the translucent gauze-like fabric, which comes down from the back of the queen's head,

110.text:
right through to the stiffness of this fabric, 
which may well be velvet,

115.text: to the very hard-edged gleaming jewels of diamonds and gold, which stud the whole of her costume.

121.text: This conservation treatment has meant that the level of detail, and the level of subtlety;

126.text:
the brilliance of the artist's technique 
is now fully evident to the eye.

131.text:
This wasn't evident originally, 
she appeared as a stiff cardboard cut-out

136.text:
but what you can see now 
is a really remarkable portrait of a queen

140.text: at the absolute height of her power.
